quote: You don't need to have kids to write a good book for kids. I don't want my kids to see themselves in my books. Their lives should be their lives.
Read Don Quixote; it is a very good book; I still read it frequently.
A good book written for children can be read by adults.

Anyways, I am a nerd, bookworm, geek... whatever you want to call me. I'm the type of person that would rather sit down and read a good book than go out and party.

Every really good book was written a little at a time, over time, in tremendous confusion and doubt.

My main piece of advice would be don't worry about being published - just write a really good book, but also don't be afraid to write a bad book. Give yourself permission to fail, and don't be afraid.

Forget romantic fiction, a survey has found that most women would rather read a good book than go shopping, have sex, or sleep.
I think we all like to get away from our troubles and worries with a good book.

I think of life as a good book. The further you get into it, the more it begins to make sense.
I feel happy and secure when I'm on my bed with a good book... I forget everything which is terrible in our world.
Reading is a conversation. All books talk. But a good book listens as well.

I enjoy art, architecture, museums, churches and temples; anything that gives me insight into the history and soul of the place I'm in. I can also be a beach bum - I like to laze in the shade of a palm tree with a good book or float in a warm sea at sundown.
Well, there's nothing better than putting your feet up on a Sunday afternoon and grabbing a good book.
I must say I find television very educational. The minute somebody turns it on, I go to the library and read a good book.

You know you've read a good book when you turn the last page and feel a little as if you have lost a friend.
Bliss is the ocean, a towel on the sand, the sun out, the chance to swim in waves or walk dragging a stick behind you, a good book, a cold drink.

A good book is a good book. End of story.
Take time to enjoy the flight - read a good book, watch a film, catch up on emails and sleep.

I don't like to be alone, but I do cherish the moments that I'm alone with a good book.
A good book is the precious lifeblood of a master spirit.

Who kills a man kills a reasonable creature, God's image, but thee who destroys a good book, kills reason its self.
Call me a nerd if you like, but I do find it hard to leave home without my laptop and a good book.

Finishing a good book is like leaving a good friend.

What makes a good book and what makes a good movie are totally different things.

One of the joys of a really good book is that you're so into the world of the book, you forget what you're looking at is words on a page.
Your life story would not make a good book. Don't even try.
Readers want a good book; it's a writer's job to give it to them.

I think it's a fallacy to say that a good book sells itself. It doesn't happen. I'm a voracious reader and I can give you a long list of books which should have been best sellers but they aren't. How can you buy a book if you haven't heard of it?
My idea of a good time is creating something and reading a good book.

I don't think any good book is based on factual experience. Bad books are about things the writer already knew before he wrote them.
Who learns most from a good book is the author.
When I'm in London, I love to visit Kensington gardens and just sit in the park and read a good book.

I don't have the time to curl up on my couch with a good book.

If only one in 1,000 people that I talk to goes on to write a good book, that's one more good book that I've helped along... and maybe it will be a book I love myself five or 10 years down the line.
I'm obsessed with books. When a good book hits me, it's all I can think about and all I can do.
You write, hoping to write a good book; that's it.
I don't drink alcohol too late in the evening; I read a good book.

I'll always be reading a good book. I don't have, like, specific genre tastes or anything or things that I kind of get hooked on, reading genre books or anything like that. It's just really anything anyone kind of recommends or is going around or I hear is good.

I'd rather write one good book than ten mediocre ones.
A good book is the best of friends, the same today and forever.

I wanted to see if I could write a good book.

When I was a teenager, reading for me was as normal, as unremarkable as eating or breathing. Reading gave flight to my imagination and strengthened my understanding of the world, the society I lived in, and myself. More importantly, reading was fun, a way to live more than one life as I immersed myself in each good book I read.
